source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: During aqueous corrosion of zirconium alloys, a fraction of the hydrogen generated by the metal-water reaction is absorbed by the metal. This hydriding can result in a loss of ductility in zirconium alloy components if hydrogen absorption is appreciable.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: Tests have shown that hydriding can be accelerated in zirconium alloys when they are coupled to other metals.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: The degree of acceleration was found to be influenced by the nature of the dissimilar metal, the amount of hydrogen dissolved in the water, the composition of the zirconium alloy, and the presence of neutron radiation.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: In neutral water at 360°C, hydrogen absorption by zirconium alloys in H₂O was up to twice as great as the equivalent hydrogen absorbed in reactor-grade D₂O.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: In tests with D₂O where alkalinity was maintained with lithium hydroxide, hydrogen rather than deuterium was the predominant species absorbed.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: Alloying additions of nickel increase the hydrogen absorption in zirconium alloys [3].

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: Large hydrogen overpressures [4] and highly alkaline solutions [5] both increase the susceptibility to hydrogen absorption in high-temperature water.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: Accelerated hydriding has been observed in zirconium alloys when in direct contact with aluminum [6] or Inconel 600 alloy [2].

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: specimens of cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb fuel sheathing were shrink-fitted onto plugs machined from nickel, Type 410 stainless steel, Type 304 stainless steel, and copper bar stock

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: the fuel sheathing (~0.46 mm thick) was given a flash pickle in a HF/H₂SO₄/HNO₃/H₂O solution

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: The specimens were exposed to hydrogenated, lithiated water at 300°C in a one-litre static autoclave.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: In Test III, there was no hydrogen overpressure in the autoclave other than that attributable to hydrogen produced by corrosion of the specimens and the inside of the autoclaves (~5.0×10⁻³ MPa)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: specimens (1 by 3 cm) taken from Zr-2.5Nb sheet (1 mm thick)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: some Zr-2.5Nb specimens were prefilmed in 400°C steam for 24 h before being coupled

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: One set of specimens was irradiated in pressurized water at 553 to 563 K for 147 days in the NRU reactor

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: The water was lithiated (pH 10.0 to 10.5) for the first 100 days and ammoniated (pH 7.2 to 7.8) for the remaining 47 days.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: Dissolved hydrogen in the water was generally less than 10 cm³ H₂/kg H₂O (25 cm³ H₂/kg H₂O maximum)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk1
evidence_span: dissolved oxygen in the water was below detectable limits (<4 μg O₂/kg H₂O)

evidence_span: Specimens (1 by 3 by $0 . 4 ~ \mathrm { c m }$ ) cut from Zr-2.5Nb and Zircaloy-2 pressure tubes

evidence_span: Specimens (1 by 3 by $0 . 4 ~ \mathrm { c m }$ ) cut from Zr-2.5Nb and Zircaloy-2 pressure tubes

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk2
evidence_span: exposed to both lithiated water $\left( \mathbf { H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { O } \right)$ and lithiated heavy water $( \mathrm { D } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O } )$ at $3 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ for three days in a static autoclave

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk2
evidence_span: exposed to both lithiated water $\left( \mathbf { H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { O } \right)$ and lithiated heavy water $( \mathrm { D } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O } )$ at $3 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ for three days in a static autoclave

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk2
evidence_span: The lithium hydroxide concentration was varied from $4 . 2 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 }$ to $\bar { 4 } . 2 \times 1 0 ^ { - 1 }$ mol/L

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk2

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk2
evidence_span: the autoclave evacuated before each start-up to exclude air

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk2
evidence_span: After each exposure, all specimens were weighed and analyzed for hydrogen or deuterium or both by the method of isotopic equilibration

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk2
evidence_span: The $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ sheaths from the plug specimens had black oxide on both the inside and outside surfaces after each of the three tests

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk2
evidence_span: Metallography showed the oxide film on all specimens to be about 1 m thick

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk3
evidence_span: Zr-2.5Nb appears more sensitive to increasing LiOH concentration than does Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk3
evidence_span: Corrosion of both Zircaloy-2 and Zr-2.5Nb is about 20% greater in H2O than in D2O at a concentration of added LiOH of 4.2×10^-1 mol/L

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk3
evidence_span: The total hydrogen absorbed in either H2O or D2O was always lower for Zr-2.5Nb than for Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk3
evidence_span: Hydrogen absorption was greatest for both alloys at an LiOH concentration of 4.2×10^-1 mol/L

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk3
evidence_span: Zr-2.5Nb absorbed about seven to nine times more hydrogen than deuterium compared with two to four times for Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk3
evidence_span: Zr-2.5Nb absorbed about seven to nine times more hydrogen than deuterium compared with two to four times for Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk3
evidence_span: the presence of LiOH appears to promote a significant increase in the total hydrogen absorption in both H2O and D2O

evidence_span: The increase in hydrogen overpressure from 1.1 to 4.5 MPa most likely increased the hydrogen absorption of the uncoupled control specimens

evidence_span: The increase in hydrogen overpressure from 1.1 to 4.5 MPa most likely increased the hydrogen absorption of the uncoupled control specimens

evidence_span: hydrogen absorption in excess of 100% recorded at extremely high (~17 MPa) overpressures

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: hydriding was influenced by contact with dissimilar metals

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: At high hydrogen overpressures, the increase in hydrogen absorption was related to the increase in hydrogen permeability of the contacting material (that is, nickel $> 4 1 0$ stainless steel $> 3 0 4$ stainless steel $>$ copper)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: The linear dependence between hydrogen absorption and the square root of the hydrogen pressure is characteristic of hydrogen permeation through nickel

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: The absence of any pressure dependence for both Types 410 and 304 stainless steel

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: increased hydrogen absorption of coupled specimens was still observed

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: increase in the specimen coupled with nickel was lower than that coupled with Type 410 stainless steel

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: oxide film on the nickel plug may have reduced its permeability to hydrogen

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: Zirconium alloys are generally considered to be anodic with respect to stainless steels and high-nickel alloys

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: Prefilming Zr-2.5Nb specimens prior to coupling with Type 410 stainless steel probably eliminated accelerated hydriding

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: The corrosion of both Zircaloy-2 and Zr-2.5Nb is strongly influenced by increasing LiOH concentration in both H2O and D2O

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: Zr-2.5Nb being the most sensitive

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: the modest increase seen in Zr-2.5Nb at the same concentration

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: the larger hydrogen absorption seen in H2O than in D2O

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: preference for hydrogen absorption in H2O compared with deuterium absorption from D2O

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_039_chunk4
evidence_span: overall preference for hydrogen over deuterium is as much as 1000 to 1 for Zircaloy-2 and up to 3000 to 1 for Zr-2.5Nb

evidence_span: overall preference for hydrogen over deuterium is as much as 1000 to 1 for Zircaloy-2 and up to 3000 to 1 for Zr-2.5Nb

evidence_span: The calculated ratio of [OD-]/[OH-] in these tests ranged from about 460 to 1 at 4.2×10^-4 mol LiOH/L to about 170 to 1 at 4.2×10^-1 mol LiOH/L

evidence_span: A strong preference for hydrogen absorption over deuterium absorption was evident in these tests
